column1: Nkhotakota (Un-kho-tah-kho-tuh) (formerly Kota Kota) (name derived from the Chichewa for "Corner Corner") is a town and one of the districts in the Central Region of Malawi. It is on the shore of Lake Malawi (formerly Lake Nyasa) and is one of the main ports on Lake Malawi. As of 2018
column2: Nkhotakota had a population estimated at 28
column3: 350. The district had a population of 301.000.

column1: == History ==

Nkhotakota was originally a group of villages in the 19th century which later served as a market for Swahili-Arabian slave traders. David Livingstone convinced Chief Jumbe to stop trading slaves under a tree in Nkhotakota in the 19th century
column2: which is currently in existence under a mission. Later Malawi president Hastings Banda gave speeches under another tree in Nkhotakota during the 1960s
column3: this one ironically known as the Livingstone Tree. This town was hit by the 2001 floods
column4: and was the worst hit area of Malawi's Central region. Today
column5: Nkhotakota is the largest traditional African town in Malawi and bears a strong Swahili-Arab influence.
